Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story:
As an engineer, I pride myself on keeping every project meticulously documented, ensuring we’re always ready for audits. This week, I finally had a stretch of quiet time—perfect for updating our safety records before the next routine audit, which is still months away. I sat at my desk, spreadsheets open, feeling the satisfaction of being ahead of schedule.

Then, my phone buzzed. It was Ahmed, a member of my congregation. He’d mentioned after Friday prayers that he wanted to talk, “whenever you have a free moment, Imam.” I knew from his tone it was important, though he hadn’t pressed for a specific time. Now, as I stared at my screen, I felt the weight of both roles. My engineering side urged me to seize this rare uninterrupted time to perfect our compliance files. But as an imam, I knew Ahmed might be struggling, waiting for guidance, and expecting me to be available when I could.

The expectations pressed in from both sides—my duty to my team and my responsibility to my community. I sat there, torn, the cursor blinking, my phone silent but heavy in my hand, unsure which role to answer first.
